How It Works Less Glue, Less Mess Most web application code is "glue code" introduced to keep everything in check. Over time, it has turned the craft of web development into a sticky mess. Domx solves the problem by creating a set of cut-and-paste components that make everything snap, not stick, together. Demos Stoplight Todo The following is a quick demo of what domx code looks like. It also features the dx-state component which is a powerful state machine that can be used to control the frontend from the backend. Click the stoplight to see it in action. Read more about the dx-state component below. dx-state demo index.html stoplight.json Click The Stoplight The stoplight is red The stoplight is yellow The stoplight is green The Markup <dx-state src="/api/stoplight.json"> <dx-text font-size="21px" font-size--960="28px">Click The Stoplight</dx-text> <dx-row id="stoplight"> <dx-box id="stoplight__red" background-color="red"></dx-box> <dx-box id="stoplight__yellow" background-color="yellow"></dx-box> <dx-box id="stoplight__green" background-color="green"></dx-box> </dx-row> <dx-state-if state="#stoplight" is="red"> <dx-text font-size="14px">The stoplight is red</dx-text> </dx-state-if> <dx-state-if state="#stoplight" is="yellow"> <dx-text font-size="14px">The stoplight is yellow</dx-text> </dx-state-if> <dx-state-if state="#stoplight" is="green"> <dx-text font-size="14px">The stoplight is green</dx-text> </dx-state-if> </dx-state> The State Machine { "initialState": "red", "listeners": [["#stoplight", "click", "changeState"]], "actions": { "reset": [ ["attr", "#stoplight__red", "opacity", "0.25"], ["attr", "#stoplight__yellow", "opacity", "0.25"], ["attr", "#stoplight__green", "opacity", "0.25"] ] }, "states": { "red": { "entry": [ ["action", "reset"], ["attr", "#stoplight__red", "opacity", "1"], ["dispatch", "changeState", 2000] ], "changeState": [["state", "yellow"]] }, "yellow": { "entry": [ ["action", "reset"], ["attr", "#stoplight__yellow", "opacity", "1"], ["dispatch", "changeState", 2000] ], "changeState": [["state", "green"]] }, "green": { "entry": [ ["action", "reset"], ["attr", "#stoplight__green", "opacity", "1"], ["dispatch", "changeState", 2000] ], "changeState": [["state", "red"]] } } } Todo Less Glue No More Sticky Mess Most web application code is "glue code" we introduce to keep everything in check. We use a disparate set of libraries to solve such things as manipulating the DOM (ui frameworks) in response to various events and state changes (state management frameworks) and try to keep everything looking good (css frameworks) while throwing things over the fence between the backend and frontend (api frameworks). The dx-state component is not required to use domx, it's just one of many components you can cut and paste into your app. However, it keeps all that glue code from becoming a sticky mess by solving it in a one simple backend language-agnostic configuration object. This means the backend can control frontend state by reading and reacting to events being emitted from the frontend. Learn more about all the things the dx-state component can do below.
